title: Week 3 Lab
contents:
Contents
Libraries we will need
Johannes helpful models for doing things with ggplot2
Question 1: Why is this graph not printing any output?
Question 2. Using the mpg dataset, graph the relationship between city milage and highway mileage by year manufacture
Question 3. Edit this graph so that the x axis and the y axis both start at 0
Question 4: what is one benefit and one limitation for this graph above (in which the x and y values start at 0?)
Quetion 5. Which of these two graphs do you prefer and why?
Quetion 6. add a facet to this graph for the “class” variable
Question 7. which graph is more informative and why?
Question 8. remove the legend from the facet graph above (g4)
Question 9 Convert the y variable to “numeric” and graph the relationship betweeen religiousity (x-axis) and `thr_mus`` (y-axis) in the ISSP dataset. Create new axis labels
Question 10. Note that I have the following graph should start from 1 and run to 4 but currently runs from 0-4. Fix the graph
Extra question 11. Find one way of improving the the following code and explain your answer

Libraries we will need


library("tidyverse")
library("patchwork")
library("readr")
library("sjPlot")
library("MASS")





# set theme
theme_set(theme_classic())



Johannes helpful models for doing things with ggplot2


library('MASS')

## Simulate data
data_lin = mvrnorm(n= 2000, mu = c(0, 0),
               Sigma = matrix(c(1, .45, .45, 1),
                              nrow=2),
               empirical = T) %>%
           data.frame(.) %>%
           mutate(group = factor(rep(c(1,2), 1000)))


## Make a scatterplot
data_lin %>%
  ggplot() +
  aes(x = X1, y = X2) +
  geom_point()



## Make a scatter by group (facet, color, size)

data_lin %>%
  ggplot() +
  aes(x = X1, y = X2, color = group) +
  geom_point()



## Make a linegraph (facet, color, size)
## Bonus make it full range


data_lin %>%
  ggplot() +
  aes(x = X1, y = X2, color = group) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")



## Make it APA

data_lin %>%
  ggplot() +
  aes(x = X1, y = X2, color = group) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  theme_classic()



## Change the axis labels to anything of your choice 

data_lin %>%
  ggplot() +
  aes(x = X1, y = X2, color = group) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  labs(x = "Axis 1", y = "Axis 2") +
  theme_classic() 



## Make a bargraph by group for variable X2 

data_lin %>%
  ggplot() +
  aes(x = group, y = X2, fill = group) +
  geom_bar(stat = "summary", fun.y = "mean")



## Bonus Make a bargraph with Errorbars  

data_plot <- Rmisc::summarySE(data_lin, "X2", "group")

data_plot %>%
  ggplot() +
  aes(x = group, y = X2, fill = group) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = X2 - ci, ymax = X2 + ci))




Question 1: Why is this graph not printing any output?


library("tidyverse")
ggplot(data = mtcars) + 
  aes(mpg, wt, colour=factor(cyl))




Question 2. Using the mpg dataset, graph the relationship between city milage and highway mileage by year manufacture
Question 3. Edit this graph so that the x axis and the y axis both start at 0


# Create graph and add title
ggplot(data = mpg) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + 
  labs(title = "Relationship bewtween engine displacement and fuel efficiency in the mpg automobile dataset") + 
  xlab("Engine displacement in (units)") + 
  ylab("Highway miles per liter")




Question 4: what is one benefit and one limitation for this graph above (in which the x and y values start at 0?)
Quetion 5. Which of these two graphs do you prefer and why?


g1 <-ggplot(data = mpg) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy, colour =  class )) + 
  labs(title = "Relationship bewtween engine displacement and fuel efficiency in the mpg automobile dataset") + 
  xlab("Engine displacement in (units)") + 
  ylab("Highway miles per liter") 





g2 <-ggplot(data = mpg) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy, shape =  class )) + 
  labs(title = "Relationship bewtween engine displacement and fuel efficiency in the mpg automobile dataset") + 
  xlab("Engine displacement in (units)") + 
  ylab("Highway miles per liter") 





library("patchwork")

g1 / g2 + plot_annotation(title = "Which plot do you prefer and why?", tag_levels = 'a')




Quetion 6. add a facet to this graph for the “class” variable


g2 <-ggplot(data = mpg) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy, shape =  class )) + 
  labs(title = "Relationship bewtween engine displacement and fuel efficiency in the mpg automobile dataset") + 
  xlab("Engine displacement in (units)") + 
  ylab("Highway miles per liter") 



Question 7. which graph is more informative and why?



Question 8. remove the legend from the facet graph above (g4)


ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = class)) +
  facet_wrap( ~ class, nrow = 2)




Question 9 Convert the y variable to “numeric” and graph the relationship betweeen religiousity (x-axis) and `thr_mus`` (y-axis) in the ISSP dataset. Create new axis labels
Download the ISSP questionaire used in this study [here]: (https://github.com/go-bayes/psych-447/blob/main/data_raw/ISSP/ISSP_2018_Religion_Questionnaire_final_version1-2.pdf)
Note1


# read the issp dataset for questionaire see: ISSP_2018_Religion_Questionnaire_final_version1-2.pdf
# 
# subset of data from the issp dataset
issp <- readr::read_csv2(url("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/go-bayes/psych-447/main/data/issp.csv"))





# note that we need to check our data
head(issp)

# when we do we find that classes of the variables need to be adjusted
str(issp)



Let’s get the data into shape using dplyr. Run this code below


ip <- issp %>%
  mutate(
    id = factor(id),
    thr_ath = as.factor(thr_ath),
    thr_bd = as.factor(thr_bd),
    thr_ch = as.factor(thr_ch),
    thr_hd = as.factor(thr_hd),
    thr_jw = as.factor(thr_jw),
    thr_ms = as.factor(thr_ms),
    neg_ath = as.factor(neg_ath),
    neg_bd = as.factor(neg_bd),
    neg_ch = as.factor(neg_ch),
    neg_hd  = as.factor(neg_hd),
    neg_jw = as.factor(neg_jw),
    neg_ms = as.factor(neg_ms),
    wave  = as.factor(wave),
    nzeuro = as.factor(nzeuro),
    eduyears = as.numeric(eduyears),
    male = as.factor(male),
    age = as.numeric(age),
    rightwing = as.numeric(rightwing),
    rural = as.factor(rural),
    religiosity = as.numeric(religiosity)
  )



Question 10. Note that I have the following graph should start from 1 and run to 4 but currently runs from 0-4. Fix the graph


library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data = ip, aes(y = as.numeric(thr_ms), x = religiosity, colour = wave))  +  geom_jitter(alpha = .1) + 
  geom_smooth(method = lm, fullrange = FALSE, alpha = 0.1) +
   scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,4))




Extra question 11. Find one way of improving the the following code and explain your answer


library(sjPlot)
plot_xtab(
    ip$thr_ms,
    ip$wave,
    show.total = F,
    show.n = F,
    geom.colors = c("lightgreen", "darkred")
  ) +
  xlab("Threatened by Muslims") +  ylab("Frequency") +
  #scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0,7)) + #theme(plot.title = element_text(size=09))
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 20, hjust = 1))





Data were collected with Barry Milne and Martin Van dataset; the data are only authorised for the purposes of teaching.↩︎

title: Week 2 Lab
contents:
Contents
Workflow
Create Repos (if you have not already)
Create R projects
Workbook 2


Workflow
If you haven’t already, set a folder for your R projects. Choose a location on our Hard drive. It is best not to use a shared folder (iCloud, Dropbox, Google Drive) because this can sometime cause problems. GitHub will be your place to store your code.
Mine is called “GIT”.
Using the methods you learned last week:
Create Repos (if you have not already)
Create a repository for 447-journals (if you don’t have one already)
Create a repository for your 447-workbooks.
You should initialise a Readme statement and a .gitignore document (make sure to click the R .gitignore)
Create R projects
Create R-projects in each of these repositories.
In your workbooks folder, using the + New Folder command, create a folder called data (or similar) This is where you’ll store your data.
Create a file called figs (where you’ll stor your figures) 5 Create a folder called workbooks, or similar this is where you’ll store your weekly workbooks.
Workbook 2
Open an R markdown document, and filling in your name
The first code chunk is for your preferences.


knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)



Find the keyboard shortcuts menu.
Memorise the keyboard shortcut for insert code chunk which is: ⌥⌘I
Use the mac to insert a code chunk.
Memorise the shortcut for evaluate which is ⌘-return^ use for all tasks in this workbook.
Use R to do 10 mathematical calculations


4+5


[1] 9



3^3


[1] 27

Show your work
Using R, find the square root of 324
In the iris dataset, find the flower with the longest Sepal.Length. (hint, use the max function.) Show the column details for this flower only.
In the iris dataset, find the flower with the shortest Sepal.Length. (hint, use the min function.)
Calculate the difference bewteen the flower with the longest and shortest Sepal.Length
Make a 7 column x 100 row dataframe using c, :, dataframe
Rename the columns of the dataframe using the names of snow white dwarfs, or any names.
Using the dataset woman, write a linear model for height ~ weight
Create a table and coefficient plot for this model
Using ggeffects, create a prediction plot for this model.

Next week we’ll be creating plots like this


library(ggplot2)
ggplot2::ggplot(data = women) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = height, y = weight)) + geom_smooth(method = lm, aes(x = height, y = weight)) + theme_classic() 




Explain what is being calculated here


sum(women$weight > 140) / length(women$weight)


[1] 0.4

Calculate the proportion of women who are over the mean weight of women






What are the advantages and disadvantages of creating more breaks in the Petal.Length indicator? Clarify your answer in a paragraph.


hist(iris$Petal.Length)






hist(iris$Petal.Length, breaks = 100)




Spot the error in this code


# here is one method. 
mh <- mean(women$height)
sum(women$weight > mh) / length(women$height)



Reorder the columns of the woman dataset so that weight comes before height. Then rename the columns “w” and “h”.



Read data into R using the following method:





# read data from file
library("readr")
testdata<- readr::read_csv(url("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/go-bayes/psych-447/main/data/testdata1.csv"))
str(testdata)



Save data into your data folder using the following method


library("here")
# save data using here
saveRDS(testdata, here::here("data", "td.RDS"))



Read data back into R


td <- readRDS(here::here("data", "td.RDS"))
str(td)



Using the td dataset, write a linear model for height ~ weight as above



Create a coefficient plot
Create a prediction plot
Extra credit, how would you interpret the intercept in this model?*

title: Week 1 Lab
contents:
Contents
Skills
Assemble
Introductions
Questions
Define the following terms related to Rmarkdown, and describe how to do them:
Answer the following questions in 1 or 2 sentences:
Rmarkdown Presentation

Introductions
Assignment: creating a journal and upload it to Blackboard
Commit your first Rmarkdown journal


Skills
Do these excercises:
https://commonmark.org/help/tutorial/
Assemble
Assemble into groups of 2 - 4 people
Introductions
Learn each others names and interests and prepare a brief introduction for the other(s)
Questions
How do you set a working directory
How do you open and close an Rmarkdown document?
Where is the difference between “source” and “console” and when might we use each?
What is “YAML”
Clarify how you found your answers
Define the following terms related to Rmarkdown, and describe how to do them:
“Knit”
“Show Outline”
“CMD-S” (command-S)
Clarify how you found the answers.
Answer the following questions in 1 or 2 sentences:
Why is it important to knit often?
What is “reproducible” research?
How might describing your analysis in Rmarkdown improve research?
What are some limitations of Rmarkdown for improving reproducible research?
Rmarkdown Presentation
Create a 2-5 slide presentation in Rmarkdown (no images required) on Rstudio GitHub, Ramrkdown
(You will not be assessed on the content of the slides – so bullet poits are up to you!)
List advantages and disadvantates of Rmarkdown presentations
Introductions
Assignment: creating a journal and upload it to Blackboard
Check that you have Rstudio and GitHub setup. If not, seek help
Commit your first Rmarkdown journal
Create your first Rmarkdown document, and title it “My Journal”
Record your impressions of the process of getting set up with RStudio and GitHub
Record any help you have offered to other people, and any help you have sought from other people, along the way.
Save the document and commit it to GitHub.
Note: set your GitHub repository to private if you wish the account to be private
Further instructions under “Labs –> Workbook_1”
